intro: Scalesia retroflexa, commonly known as the giant hibiscus, is a striking plant native to the Galápagos Islands. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its large, showy flowers that can reach up to 30 centimeters in diameter. The plant has a woody stem and broad, heart-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, white waxy coating. It thrives in the humid, tropical climate of its native habitat and is adapted to the unique ecological conditions of the Galápagos. Due to its size and ornamental value, it is also cultivated in botanical gardens around the world.
